arm_group.description:
30 voluntary therapists from 9 mental health services will be trained and coached in IMR.
100 patients from the 9 mental health services will receive Illness Management and Recovery from the therapists in training.

brief_summary.textblock:
The purpose of this study is to examine the barriers and facilitators of implementing
      Illness Management and Recovery (IMR) in Norwegian mental health services.

clinical_study.brief_title: Implementation of Illness Management and Recovery in Mental Health Services

detailed_description.textblock:
IMR is an evidence-based practice developed for people with severe mental illnesses. It is
      based on the principles of recovery to help people set individual meaningful goals for their
      lives and gain illness self-management skills and thereby contribute to their individual
      recovery-process. IMR can be given individually or in groups, once a week for 10-12 months.

      In this project the investigators will implement Illness Management and Recovery (IMR) in
      mental health services. The implementation strategy are carried out according to the IMR
      toolkits which include informational and training materials, implementation recommendations,
      and fidelity scales to facilitate use of the model in routine practices. The implementation
      process and outcome will be of main focus.

      The study has an observational prospective cohort design. 30 therapists from 9 different
      mental health services will be trained and supervised in IMR. The investigators aim to enrol
      100 patients. The primary outcome is patients' recovery outcomes in the IMR program.
      Secondary outcomes are patients' level of functioning and hope, organisational
      implementation outcome, and  therapists' fidelity and integrity to the model.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria Therapists:

          -  Voluntary recruited therapists in the participating mental health services

          -  trained and consulted in IMR

        Inclusion Criteria Patients:

          -  Adults (18+)

          -  Associated with one of the participating mental health services

          -  symptoms on or diagnosis of severe mental illness with or without drug abuse

          -  giving informed consent verbally and in writing

        Exclusion Criteria Patients:

          -  Patients with acute risk of suicidal behaviour

          -  not able to communicate in Norwegian

intervention.description: Evidence-based practice given individually or in groups, weekly for 10-12 months.

clinical_study.official_title: Implementation of Illness Management and Recovery in Mental Health Services: Facilitators and Barriers in the Implementation Process.

overall_official.affiliation: Akershus University Hospital, Research & Development, Mental Health Services

oversight_info.authority: Norway:National Committee for Medical and Health Research Ethics

primary_outcome.description: Assessing patients' recovery outcomes in the IMR program with 15 items.
primary_outcome.measure: The Illness Management and Recovery Scale (SAMHSA, 2009)
primary_outcome.time_frame: About 11 months after start of intervention

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

secondary_outcome.description: Assesses the degree of fidelity with 13 items on a 5-point likert scale where 5 indicates full implementation and 0 indicates no implementation
A 12-item scale measuring organisational outcome of implementation by common agency practices that support evidence-based practices
A 16-item scale measuring clinicians' faithful replication of the model
secondary_outcome.measure: The Illness Management & Recovery Treatment Integrity Scale (IT-IS) (McGuire et al., 2012

secondary_outcome.description: A 6-item self-report scale of patients' hope and optimism
secondary_outcome.measure: The Adult State Hope Scale (Snyder et al., 1996)
The Global Assessment of Functioning Scale (GAF) (Goldman, Skodol, & Lave, 1992
